title: A Theranos Timeline: The Downfall of Elizabeth Holmes, a Silicon Valley Superstar; The rise and fall of the blood-testing startup founder has played out over 18 years
text:
2007 — Theranos is valued at an estimated $197 million after raising another $43.2 million from investors.

2009 — Ramesh "Sunny" Balwani joins the company as the number-two executive. Ms. Holmes doesn't widely disclose that the two, who met the summer before she started college, are also romantically involved.

2010 — Another fundraising round boosts Theranos's valuation above $1 billion, putting the company in an elite rank of highly-valued startups.

2011 — Former U.S. Secretary of State George Shultz joins Theranos's board. In the years that followed, the board would come to include a renowned group of political and business leaders, including retired Marine Corps Gen. Jim Mattis, former Secretary of State Henry Kissinger, attorney David Boies and former Wells Fargo Chief Executive Richard Kovacevich.

2013 — Theranos begins offering blood tests to the public in Arizona and California, mostly through a partnership with Walgreens Boots Alliance Inc. pharmacies.

2014 — Theranos's valuation rises to $9 billion. Ms. Holmes is now worth $4.5 billion on paper and considered the youngest self-made female billionaire.

Oct. 15, 2015 — The Wall Street Journal publishes its first in a series of articles exposing shortcomings with Theranos's technology. The Journal reports that most of Theranos's blood tests aren't run on their proprietary devices, but instead on commercial blood analyzers that have sometimes been altered to work with small amounts of blood.

Oct. 21, 2015 — Speaking at a Wall Street Journal conference, Ms. Holmes stands by her company's achievements but says the company is in a "pause period" while seeking federal approval of its proprietary technology.

January 2016 — The Centers for Medicare and Medicaid Services says that a November inspection of Theranos's California lab uncovered deficient practices that pose immediate jeopardy to patient health and safety.

May 2016 — Mr. Balwani leaves the company as part of a broad reorganization.

October 2016 — Theranos closes its medical lab operations amid regulatory scrutiny. The company says it will shrink its workforce by more than 40% and refocus on developing a miniaturized blood-testing device to sell to third parties.

April 18, 2017 — The Arizona attorney general announces that all Arizonans who purchased a Theranos test can get a full refund under a $4.65 million settlement with the company.

May 2017 — Theranos settles a lawsuit brought by investor Partner Fund Management seeking to recoup the $96 billion investment it made in the company in 2014. Neither side disclosed terms of the deal. The company also cut a deal with late-stage investors to give them additional shares in exchange for a promise not to sue.

March 2018 — The Securities and Exchange Commission charges Theranos, Ms. Holmes and Mr. Balwani with civil-securities fraud. Theranos and Ms. Holmes reach settlements without admitting or denying any liability.

June 15, 2018 — Federal prosecutors bring criminal-fraud charges against Ms. Holmes and Mr. Balwani. The initial indictment detailed two counts of conspiracy to commit wire fraud and nine counts of wire fraud. The total number of wire fraud charges later rises to 10.

July 22, 2018 — Theranos settles with additional investors who had sued the company.

June 2019 — A federal judge sets Ms. Holmes's trial for July 2020, a date that will be repeatedly delayed because of the Covid-19 pandemic.

March 12, 2021 — Ms. Holmes tells the court she is pregnant, delaying her criminal trial once again.

July 2021 — Ms. Holmes gives birth to a baby boy.

Aug. 31, 2021 — Jury selection begins in Ms. Holmes's criminal trial. Opening statements and witness testimony start a week later.
